Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the step-parent should provide guidance
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, watching my stepson fidget with his spoon, milk dribbling down his chin. He’d just snapped at me when I reminded him to say “please” before asking for more cereal. I knew I needed to be patient, to guide him gently, to show him the right way to treat others. That’s what a good step-parent does—teaches, corrects, and models respect. But my mind kept drifting to the notice I’d seen at the construction site earlier: an optional training session next week, right after my shift. The foreman had hinted that those who attended would be first in line for overtime. I wanted to be seen as reliable, a team player, someone who took the job seriously. But the training was at the same time as the evening routine at home, when my stepson needed me most. I felt the pressure building inside—torn between being the steady hand at home and the dependable worker on site. Both roles demanded my presence, my attention, my best self. I stared at my stepson, unsure which part of me should take the lead.
